deliberation: Checked for metaphorical or personified language. Only non-literal element is the idiomatic phrase בְּיַד יִרְמְיָהוּ, using “hand” for agency. The rest is formulaic prophetic heading.

instances.english_text: through the hand of Jeremiah the prophet
instances.explanation: ‘Hand’ stands metonymically/idiomatically for Jeremiah’s agency as the instrument through whom God’s word is delivered.

deliberation: Looked for metaphors and personifications. The main figurative element is that Bel, Merodach, and the idols are said to be shamed and dismayed, treating lifeless idols as sentient beings.

instances.hebrew_text: הֹבִישׁ בֵּל חַת מְרֹדָךְ הֹבִישׁוּ עֲצַבֶּיהָ חַתּוּ גִּלּוּלֶיהָ
instances.english_text: Bel is shamed, Merodach is dismayed. Her idols are shamed, her fetishes dismayed.
posture: mocking exposure of the impotence of Babylon’s gods
instances.explanation: Inanimate idols and foreign deities are portrayed as feeling shame and terror, personifying them to emphasize their impotence before Israel’s God.

deliberation: Considered whether “from man to beast” is merely exhaustive or a figure of totality. It functions as a merism expressing complete depopulation.

instances.english_text: Both human and animal shall wander away.
target: all living inhabitants of the land
ground: exhaustive scope including all living beings
instances.explanation: The pairing ‘man and beast’ is a merism that conveys the idea that every kind of inhabitant will be gone, stressing the completeness of the devastation.

deliberation: Expressions like ‘seek the LORD’ are conventional covenant language for religious turning and can be taken literally in a theological sense. No clear metaphor, simile, or other figurative image beyond standard diction.
Examined directional language and covenant language. ‘Join themselves to the LORD’ uses physical attachment as a metaphor for entering loyal covenant relationship.

instances.english_text: They shall come and attach themselves to GOD
target: Israel and Judah’s renewed loyalty to God
posture: positive portrayal of restored covenant intimacy
instances.explanation: The verb ‘attach themselves’ is metaphorical, depicting covenantal loyalty to God as physical adherence or joining to a person.

deliberation: This verse clearly uses extended shepherding imagery. Identified at least two distinct metaphors: God’s people as lost sheep, and their leaders as misleading shepherds.

instances.english_text: My people were lost sheep
ground: vulnerability, lack of direction, susceptibility to harm
posture: compassionate but critical diagnosis of Israel’s state
instances.explanation: Israel is compared to ‘lost sheep,’ emphasizing their vulnerable, directionless state and need for proper guidance.

instances.english_text: their shepherds led them astray
ground: responsibility for guidance and care, and failure in that role
posture: strong criticism of the leaders’ misguidance
instances.explanation: The leaders are metaphorically called ‘shepherds,’ portraying them as those meant to guide and protect the flock but instead misleading them.

deliberation: Noted predator imagery (‘devoured’), and titles for God (‘habitation of righteousness’) that are metaphorical. Selected two distinct figures: enemies devouring Israel, and the LORD as a true pasture/habitation.

instances.english_text: All who encountered them devoured them
target: the nations’ violent treatment of Israel
posture: condemnation of the nations’ excessive cruelty
instances.explanation: The enemies’ oppression of Israel is likened to animals devouring prey, stressing its rapacious and destructive character.

instances.english_text: they have sinned against the LORD, the true Pasture
target: the LORD’s role for His people
ground: source of security, nourishment, and right order
posture: affirmation of God as the proper sustaining environment for His people
instances.explanation: Calling the LORD ‘habitation/pasture of righteousness’ metaphorically presents Him as the environment where His people are meant to be safely nourished in justice.

deliberation: Main figure is an explicit simile urging the people to be like leading he-goats. Fleeing Babylon itself is literal exhortation.

instances.english_text: And be like he-goats that lead the flock!
ground: taking initiative and leading others out
posture: urgent encouragement to decisive, exemplary action
instances.explanation: The exiles are urged to act like he-goats who go before the flock, a simile picturing them as leaders initiating the escape.

deliberation: Imagery of arrows and warriors is largely literal military language, but the clause ‘his arrows are like a skilled warrior’ is a simile stressing their unfailing effectiveness.

instances.hebrew_text: חִצָּיו כְּגִבּוֹר מַשְׂכִּיל לֹא יָשׁוּב רֵיקָם
instances.english_text: Their arrows are like those of a skilled warrior who does not turn back without hitting the mark.
target: the invading army’s attacks on Babylon
instances.explanation: The arrows are compared to those of a warrior who never returns empty-handed, highlighting how certain and effective the coming attacks will be.

deliberation: The only potentially figurative element is ‘shall be sated,’ using the language of physical satisfaction for satisfaction with spoil, a common metaphor.

instances.english_text: All her spoilers shall be sated
posture: matter-of-fact prediction of the invaders’ enrichment
instances.explanation: The plunderers’ satisfaction is described with a verb for being ‘sated’ with food, metaphorically applying bodily fullness to material gain.

deliberation: This verse is rich in animal imagery. Identified: Israel as ‘My possession/heritage,’ a livestock simile (‘like a threshing heifer’), and a simile (‘you neigh like strong horses’).

instances.english_text: You who plundered My possession
posture: indignant highlighting of Babylon’s violation of what belongs to God
instances.explanation: Calling Israel ‘My possession/heritage’ metaphorically portrays them as God’s personal inheritance that Babylon has plundered.

instances.english_text: like a heifer treading grain
target: Babylon’s arrogant joy in plundering Israel
ground: carefree energy, unrestrained movement and enjoyment
posture: censure of Babylon’s gloating over its exploitation
instances.explanation: Babylon’s exultant plundering is compared to a heifer trampling grain, depicting unrestrained, almost playful enjoyment of gain.

instances.english_text: you neighed like steeds
ground: noisy, uncontrolled, and perhaps sensual excitement
instances.explanation: Their gloating is likened to stallions’ neighing, evoking noisy, unrestrained, almost animalistic excitement.

deliberation: Main figure is Babylon’s ‘mother’ being ashamed, a metaphor for the source (land/dynasty) that produced Babylon’s population or power. The wilderness words describe the final state and can be taken literally within prophetic vision.

instances.english_text: So your mother will be utterly shamed, She who bore you will be disgraced.
target: the source of Babylon’s people/power (land, city, dynasty)
vehicle: a human mother who is ashamed of her children
ground: disgrace reflected on one’s source or origin
posture: humiliating Babylon by extending shame to its very origins
instances.explanation: The land/dynasty that produced Babylon is personified as a mother humiliated by her offspring’s fate, underscoring total disgrace.

deliberation: Identified metaphor in ‘all her wounds’ for Babylon’s ruined state, treating the city as a wounded body. The hissing/whistling is a conventional reaction of derision to devastation, but the key figure is the bodily imagery.

instances.english_text: And will hiss at all her wounds.
instances.explanation: Babylon’s physical and political ruin is depicted as ‘wounds’ on a body, personifying the city to stress how badly it has been struck.

deliberation: Commands to archers and statement that she has sinned against the LORD are straightforward prophetic-military language without overt metaphor or personification beyond standard theology.
Key figure is the idiom ‘she has given her hand’ for surrender. The rest (falling bastions, walls, vengeance) is literal in the prophetic portrayal.

instances.english_text: She has surrendered (lit. ‘she has given her hand’)
ground: yielding oneself into another’s power, making terms
posture: announcing Babylon’s forced submission as divinely wrought
instances.explanation: The idiom ‘give the hand’ functions metonymically for entering a submissive agreement, here personifying Babylon as a woman surrendering.

deliberation: Agricultural and military references (sower, harvester, sword, fleeing) all function literally within the war oracle. No clear metaphor or figurative pattern beyond standard diction.
Continues and intensifies pastoral/predator imagery. Identified (1) Israel as a scattered sheep, and (2) Assyria/Nebuchadrezzar as lions who devour and crunch bones.

instances.english_text: Israel are scattered sheep
ground: isolation, exposure, and lack of protective oversight
instances.explanation: Israel’s political and spiritual dispersion is depicted as a sheep scattered from its flock, highlighting its defenselessness.

instances.hebrew_text: אֲרָיוֹת הִדִּיחוּ הָרִאשׁוֹן אֲכָלוֹ ... וְזֶה הָאַחֲרוֹן עִצְּמוֹ
instances.english_text: harried by lions. First the king of Assyria devoured them, and in the end King Nebuchadrezzar of Babylon crunched their bones.
target: Assyria’s and Babylon’s treatment of Israel
ground: ferocity, thoroughness of destruction, and terror
posture: severe condemnation of the empires’ brutality
instances.explanation: The kings are portrayed as lions who not only devour but crunch Israel’s bones, a vivid hyperbolic metaphor for merciless and thorough devastation.

deliberation: Statements about God ‘visiting/punishing’ the king and land of Babylon as He did Assyria are standard prophetic-legal language and function literally within the theological framework.
Builds on the sheep imagery: Israel led back to ‘his pasture’ and grazing in named regions. Though those are real places, the shepherding verbs create a pastoral metaphor for restoration.

instances.hebrew_text: וְשֹׁבַבְתִּי אֶת־יִשְׂרָאֵל אֶל־נָוֵהוּ וְרָעָה הַכַּרְמֶל וְהַבָּשָׁן
instances.english_text: And I will lead Israel back to his pasture, and he shall graze in Carmel and Bashan
vehicle: a flock led back to its pasture to graze
posture: warm assurance of abundant restoration under divine care
instances.explanation: Israel’s return and flourishing are pictured as a sheep being brought back to rich pasture and grazing there, continuing the pastoral metaphor.

deliberation: Here iniquity and sins are ‘sought’ but ‘not found’, using searching for objects as a metaphor for judicial investigation finding guilt.

instances.hebrew_text: יְבֻקַּשׁ אֶת־עֲוֺן יִשְׂרָאֵל וְאֵינֶנּוּ וְאֶת־חַטֹּאת יְהוּדָה וְלֹא תִמָּצֶאנָה
instances.english_text: The iniquity of Israel shall be sought, And there shall be none; The sins of Judah, And none shall be found
target: Israel’s and Judah’s guilt before God
ground: the presence or absence of incriminating evidence
posture: joyful assurance of complete forgiveness and removal of guilt
instances.explanation: Guilt is portrayed as something that could be sought and found like an object; its absence signifies full pardon.

deliberation: Much is straightforward military command. However, the toponyms Merathaim (‘Double Rebellion’) and Pekod (‘Punishment’) are probably deliberate wordplays/renamings that function as ironic labels for Babylon, a figurative device.

instances.english_text: against her—the land of Merathaim— And against the inhabitants of Pekod
target: the land and people of Babylon/Chaldea
ground: their extreme guilt and destined punishment
posture: ironic stigmatizing of Babylon through punning place names
instances.explanation: By using place names that sound like ‘double rebellion’ and ‘punishment,’ the prophet metonymically labels Babylon according to its crimes and fate.

deliberation: ‘Sound of war in the land and great breaking’ is elevated style but functions literally for warfare and destruction. No clear metaphor or simile beyond standard prophetic diction.
Clear, central metaphor: Babylon as ‘the hammer of the whole earth’ now broken. No other distinct figures beyond this image of Babylon’s former power.

instances.english_text: the hammer of the whole earth
vehicle: a hammer that strikes the whole earth
ground: ability to crush, subdue, and shape others
posture: triumphant depiction of the smashing of world-dominating power
instances.explanation: Babylon is metaphorically called ‘the hammer of the whole earth,’ suggesting its former role in violently subduing nations, now itself cut off and shattered.

deliberation: Judgment described through hunter imagery: setting a snare, catching Babylon. This is a clear metaphor for how God’s judgment overtakes Babylon unexpectedly.

instances.hebrew_text: יָקֹשְׁתִּי לָךְ וְגַם־נִלְכַּדְתְּ בָּבֶל ... נִמְצֵאת וְגַם־נִתְפַּשְׂתְּ
instances.english_text: I set a snare for you, O Babylon, And you were trapped unawares; You were found and caught
vehicle: an animal caught in a snare or trap
posture: assertion of God’s active, cunning judgment against Babylon
instances.explanation: God’s judgment on Babylon is likened to a hunter setting a snare in which Babylon, personified as prey, is unsuspectingly caught.

deliberation: God is described as opening His storehouse and bringing out ‘weapons of wrath.’ This anthropomorphic military-metaphorical depiction portrays divine judgment as an armory deployment.

instances.hebrew_text: פָּתַח יְהוָה אֶת־אוֹצָרוֹ וַיּוֹצֵא אֶת־כְּלֵי זַעְמוֹ
instances.english_text: GOD has opened the divine armory And brought out the weapons of wrath
target: God’s execution of judgment on Chaldea
vehicle: a warrior opening his armory and taking weapons
posture: depicts God as a divine warrior fully equipped to judge
instances.explanation: Divine judgments (likely invading armies, disasters) are portrayed as ‘weapons’ taken from God’s armory, an anthropomorphic metaphor of God as warrior.

deliberation: Beyond literal plundering of granaries, the command ‘pile her up like heaps [of grain]’ is a simile, picturing the city itself as a mound of harvested product to be destroyed.

instances.english_text: Pile her up like heaps of grain
target: Babylon’s populace and wealth to be destroyed
ground: being amassed into mounds ready for removal or destruction
posture: vivid command to utterly overwhelm and clear away Babylon
instances.explanation: The city is to be treated like grain being heaped up, evoking the image of Babylon reduced to stacked spoil or rubble ready for removal.

deliberation: The bulls likely represent strong leaders/warriors, using livestock imagery. ‘Day of their visitation’ is standard prophetic idiom, but the main figure is the metaphor of bulls for powerful men.

instances.english_text: Destroy all her bulls, Let them go down to slaughter.
target: Babylon’s strong leaders and elite warriors
ground: strength combined with utter helplessness before slaughter
posture: announcing the doom of Babylon’s strongest as sacrificial victims
instances.explanation: Calling them ‘bulls’ metaphorically highlights both their former strength and their now-helpless fate as victims led to slaughter.

deliberation: ‘Voice of fugitives’ and ‘vengeance for the temple’ are within standard prophetic idiom. The language is basically literal (escaped people reporting God’s vengeance) without marked figurative imagery.
War summons and lex talionis (‘according to her work’) are conventional legal-moral language. No distinct metaphor or simile beyond that standard framework in this verse.
The description of young men falling in streets and warriors silenced is direct portrayal of battle casualties/death, not obviously figurative here.
Abstract ‘Pride/Insolence’ (זָדוֹן) is vocatively addressed as an enemy, personifying Babylon’s arrogance as a figure confronted by God.

instances.english_text: I am going to deal with you, O Insolence
target: Babylon as characterized by arrogant pride
ground: embodiment of arrogance as an opponent of God
posture: declaring direct divine opposition to Babylon’s pride
instances.explanation: The term ‘Insolence’ stands metonymically for Babylon and is personified as a foe whom God confronts and punishes.

deliberation: Continues the personification of Insolence: it ‘stumbles and falls’ and has ‘no one to raise her.’ These bodily actions are metaphorical for Babylon’s humiliating collapse.

instances.hebrew_text: וְכָשַׁל זָדוֹן וְנָפַל וְאֵין לוֹ מֵקִים
instances.english_text: Insolence shall stumble and fall, With none to raise her up.
vehicle: a person stumbling, falling, and not being helped up
ground: loss of stability, humiliation, and abandonment
posture: emphasizing the finality and helplessness of Babylon’s collapse
instances.explanation: ‘Insolence’ (Babylon’s pride) is depicted as a person who trips and falls with no helper, a personified metaphor for irreversible humiliation.

deliberation: Oppression and captivity are historically literal descriptions of Israel and Judah under foreign rule; no distinct metaphor or simile beyond standard legal-social language.

Uses legal imagery: God as ‘Redeemer’ and one who ‘pleads their cause’, a courtroom metaphor for divine advocacy. Also a world-rest vs. Babylon’s unrest contrast, but primary figure is legal advocacy.

instances.english_text: Their mighty Redeemer, Whose name is GOD of Hosts, Will champion their cause
vehicle: a family ‘redeemer’ and legal advocate pleading a case
ground: obligated defense and rescue of vulnerable kin
posture: assurance that God will act as both kinsman and lawyer for His people
instances.explanation: God is portrayed as a powerful kinsman-redeemer and courtroom advocate who takes up Israel’s lawsuit, a legal-family metaphor for deliverance.

deliberation: ‘A sword against the Chaldeans’ is stock prophetic shorthand where ‘sword’ stands metonymically for warfare and violent judgment, not just the literal object.

instances.english_text: A sword against the Chaldeans ... And against the inhabitants of Babylon
target: coming violent judgment and defeat of the Chaldeans
ground: infliction of lethal force and defeat
posture: solemn declaration of divinely decreed warfare
instances.explanation: ‘Sword’ functions metonymically for the warfare and judgment that will fall upon the Chaldeans, not only the physical blade.

deliberation: Continues the ‘sword against’ formula; again the sword stands for the onset of war that renders diviners fools and warriors dismayed.

instances.english_text: A sword against the diviners ... A sword against the warriors
target: impending defeat of Babylon’s religious and military elites
ground: overwhelming destructive force that nullifies their power
posture: stripping Babylon’s elites of competence and courage through divine war
instances.explanation: Here ‘sword’ again metonymically denotes the destructive warfare that will render diviners foolish and warriors terrified.

deliberation: Two figures: (1) ‘sword against’ continuing as metonymy for war; (2) ‘they shall become women’ as a metaphor for becoming weak and fearful in battle.

instances.english_text: A sword against its horses and chariots ... A sword against its treasuries
posture: depicting comprehensive dismantling of Babylon’s military and economic strength
instances.explanation: Again ‘sword’ stands metonymically for the war that will consume Babylon’s forces and riches.

instances.english_text: That they become women!
ground: fearfulness, lack of martial courage in that cultural context
posture: contemptuous portrayal of their collapse in courage
instances.explanation: In ancient war rhetoric, to ‘become women’ metaphorically meant losing manly courage, depicting the troops as suddenly weak and fearful.

deliberation: Drought against waters is likely literal within the judgment imagery. The main figurative note is that they ‘go mad’ over their dreadful images, a metaphor of idolatry as madness/inebriation with terror.

instances.english_text: For it is a land of idols; They are besotted by their dread images.
ground: irrational, self-destructive attachment mixed with fear
posture: sharp critique of idolatry as a kind of insanity
instances.explanation: The people are said to ‘go wild’ over fearsome images, metaphorically portraying idol worship as crazed infatuation with terrifying things.

deliberation: Animal inhabitants (wildcats, hyenas, ostriches) can be literal features of desolation imagery. The specifically figurative element is the absolute ‘never again be inhabited ... to all generations,’ functioning as hyperbolic totality.

instances.hebrew_text: וְלֹא־תֵשֵׁב עוֹד לָנֶצַח וְלֹא תִשְׁכּוֹן עַד־דּוֹר וָדֹר
instances.english_text: It shall never be settled again, Nor inhabited throughout the ages.
ground: emphasis on the permanence and completeness of desolation
posture: underscoring irrevocable judgment in sweeping terms
instances.explanation: The repeated ‘never’ and ‘through all generations’ exaggerate the permanence of Babylon’s desolation to stress total and lasting judgment.

deliberation: Uses an explicit simile comparing Babylon’s overthrow to God’s destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah, to communicate degree and kind of devastation.

instances.english_text: It shall be as when God overthrew Sodom and Gomorrah
target: the nature of Babylon’s coming destruction
vehicle: God’s overthrow of Sodom and Gomorrah
ground: suddenness, totality, and divine origin of destruction
posture: intensifying the warning by aligning Babylon with the archetypal destroyed cities
instances.explanation: Babylon’s ruin is likened to the famous destruction of Sodom and Gomorrah to express how absolute and divinely wrought it will be.

deliberation: ‘From the remotest parts of the earth’ (מִיַּרְכְּתֵי־אָרֶץ) is idiomatic hyperbole for very distant regions, not a literal cosmological statement.

instances.english_text: From the remotest parts of the earth.
target: geographical origin of the invading nations
posture: highlighting the surprising and far-reaching nature of the coalition against Babylon
instances.explanation: The phrase uses spatial hyperbole, picturing the invaders as coming from the far ends of the earth to stress their distant and overwhelming origin.

deliberation: Two figures: (1) ‘their sound is like the sea roaring’ is a simile for the army’s loud approach; (2) ‘daughter of Babylon’ personifies the city/empire as a woman.

instances.english_text: The sound of them is like the roaring sea.
target: the noise and terror of the invading army
ground: loud, continuous, overwhelming sound and force
posture: aims to evoke dread at the unstoppable approach of the invaders
instances.explanation: The army’s sound is compared to the sea’s roar, a simile emphasizing their overwhelming and terrifying presence.

instances.english_text: Against you, O Fair Babylon! (lit. ‘daughter of Babylon’)
ground: vulnerability, identity as a single personified figure
posture: intimate yet condemning address to Babylon as a personified woman
instances.explanation: ‘Daughter of Babylon’ personifies the city as a woman, a common prophetic metaphor for a city or people under judgment.

deliberation: Contains bodily idiom (‘his hands are slack/weakened’) and an explicit simile comparing his anguish to a woman in childbirth. The childbirth pangs simile is the clearest figurative element.

instances.english_text: Pangs like a woman in childbirth.
target: the king of Babylon’s terror and anguish
vehicle: labor pains of a woman giving birth
ground: sudden, uncontrollable, and extreme pain and fear
posture: humiliating comparison of a mighty king’s fear to childbirth labor pains
instances.explanation: The king’s anguish is likened to a woman’s labor pains, a simile highlighting the extremity and inevitability of his distress.

deliberation: Primary image: God’s action likened to a lion emerging from the Jordan thickets to attack a secure pasture—a simile. Also uses shepherd imagery rhetorically (‘who is shepherd that can stand before me?’), but the lion-pasture simile is central.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנֵּה כְּאַרְיֵה יַעֲלֶה מִגְּאוֹן הַיַּרְדֵּן אֶל־נְוֵה אֵיתָן
instances.english_text: It shall be as when a lion comes out of the jungle of the Jordan against a secure pasture
target: God’s sudden, forceful intervention against Babylon
vehicle: a lion leaving the Jordan thickets to attack a pasture
ground: suddenness, ferocity, and the helplessness of prey
posture: assertion of God’s unmatched predatory power over Babylon’s supposed security
instances.explanation: God’s move against Babylon is compared to a lion springing from the Jordan’s thickets to seize prey in a secure pasture, emphasizing surprise and ferocity.

deliberation: Shepherding imagery returns: ‘the little ones of the flock will drag them away’ and ‘He will make their pasture desolate.’ This applies flock language to Babylon, forming a metaphor of Babylon as a flock ravaged by even weak attackers.

instances.hebrew_text: אִם־לֹא יִסְחָבוּם צְעִירֵי הַצֹּאן אִם־לֹא יַשִּׁים עֲלֵיהֶם נָוֶה
instances.english_text: Surely the shepherd boys Shall drag them away; Surely the pasture shall be aghast because of them.
target: Babylon and its leaders who will be displaced
vehicle: little ones of the flock and a ravaged pasture
ground: the humiliation of mighty ones dragged off by the weak; total disruption of their secure environment
posture: ironic portrayal of Babylon’s humiliation and the devastation of its ‘pasture’
instances.explanation: Babylon is pictured as a flock whose young are able to drag it away, and its pasture left aghast, a metaphor for humiliating defeat and ruined dwelling-place.

deliberation: ‘The earth quakes’ at the sound of Babylon’s capture is stock hyperbolic language in prophets for extreme political upheaval; not necessarily a literal seismic event.

instances.english_text: The earth quakes
ground: great disturbance and shock affecting all
posture: underscoring the worldwide impact of Babylon’s downfall
instances.explanation: The ‘earth’ is said to quake, personifying the world and using hyperbole to depict the immense shock of Babylon’s capture among the nations.
